children.help:
This is the maximum size of the data portion of HCI ACL data packets.
It does not include the HCI data header (of 4 bytes)
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_TRANSPORT_ACL_SIZE
children.title: Transport ACL Buffer size

children.help:
This is the size of each HCI event buffer in bytes. In case of
extended advertising, packets can be fragmented. 257 bytes is the
maximum size of a packet.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_TRANSPORT_EVT_SIZE
children.title: Transport Event Buffer size

children.help:
This is the high priority HCI events' buffer size. High-priority
event buffers are for everything except advertising reports. If there
are no free high-priority event buffers then host will try to allocate a
low-priority buffer instead
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_TRANSPORT_EVT_COUNT
children.title: Transport Event Buffer count

children.help:
This is the low priority HCI events' buffer size. Low-priority event
buffers are only used for advertising reports. If there are no free
low-priority event buffers, then an incoming advertising report will
get dropped
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_TRANSPORT_EVT_DISCARD_COUNT
children.title: Discardable Transport Event Buffer count

children.help: Maximum number of GATT client procedures that can be executed.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_GATT_MAX_PROCS
children.title: Maximum number of GATT client procedures

children.help: Host flow control interval in msecs
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_HS_FLOW_CTRL_ITVL
children.title: Host Flow control interval

children.help:
Host flow control threshold, if the number of free buffers are at or
below this threshold, send an immediate number-of-completed-packets
event
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_HS_FLOW_CTRL_THRESH
children.title: Host Flow control threshold

children.help:
Enable this option to send number-of-completed-packets event to
controller after disconnection
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_HS_FLOW_CTRL_TX_ON_DISCONNECT
children.title: Host Flow control on disconnect

children.help: Enable Host Flow control
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_HS_FLOW_CTRL
children.title: Enable Host Flow control

children.help:
Time interval between RPA address change. This is applicable in case of
Host based RPA
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_RPA_TIMEOUT
children.title: RPA timeout in seconds

children.help:
Enable proxy. This is automatically set whenever NIMBLE_MESH_PB_GATT or
NIMBLE_MESH_GATT_PROXY is set
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_PROXY
children.title: Enable mesh proxy functionality

children.help:
Enable this option to allow the device to be provisioned over
the advertising bearer
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_PB_ADV
children.title: Enable mesh provisioning over advertising bearer

children.help:
Enable this option to allow the device to be provisioned over the GATT
bearer
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_PB_GATT
children.title: Enable mesh provisioning over GATT bearer

children.help: Enable mesh provisioning
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_PROV
children.title: Enable BLE mesh provisioning

children.help:
This option enables support for the Mesh GATT Proxy Service,
i.e. the ability to act as a proxy between a Mesh GATT Client
and a Mesh network
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_GATT_PROXY
children.title: Enable GATT Proxy functionality

children.help: Support for acting as a Mesh Relay Node
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_RELAY
children.title: Enable mesh relay functionality

children.help: Enable this option to be able to act as a Low Power Node
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_LOW_POWER
children.title: Enable mesh low power mode

children.help: Enable this option to be able to act as a Friend Node
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_FRIEND
children.title: Enable mesh friend functionality

children.help: This value defines Bluetooth Mesh device/node name
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_DEVICE_NAME
children.title: Set mesh device name

children.help: Defines mesh node count.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_NODE_COUNT
children.title: Set mesh node count

children.help: Enable mesh provisioner.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH_PROVISIONER
children.title: Enable BLE mesh provisioner

children.help:
Enable BLE Mesh example present in upstream mynewt-nimble and not maintained by Espressif.

IDF maintains ESP-BLE-MESH as the official Mesh solution. Please refer to ESP-BLE-MESH guide at:
`https://docs.espressif.com/projects/esp-idf/en/latest/esp32/api-guides/esp-ble-mesh/ble-mesh-index.html`
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MESH
children.title: Enable BLE mesh functionality

children.help:
Enable this option to choose mbedTLS instead of TinyCrypt for crypto
computations.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_CRYPTO_STACK_MBEDTLS
children.title: Override TinyCrypt with mbedTLS for crypto computations

children.help: BLE Host stop procedure timeout in milliseconds.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_HS_STOP_TIMEOUT_MS
children.title: BLE host stop timeout in msec

children.help:
Use this option to do host based Random Private Address resolution.
If this option is disabled then controller based privacy is used.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_HOST_BASED_PRIVACY
children.title: Enable host based privacy for random address.

children.help: Defines maximum number of connection reattempts.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MAX_CONN_REATTEMPT
children.title: Maximum number connection reattempts

children.help:
Enable to make the NimBLE host to reattempt GAP connection on connection
establishment failure.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_ENABLE_CONN_REATTEMPT
children.title: Enable connection reattempts on connection establishment error

children.help: Enable 2M-PHY
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_LL_CFG_FEAT_LE_2M_PHY
children.title: Enable 2M Phy

children.help: Enable coded-PHY
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_LL_CFG_FEAT_LE_CODED_PHY
children.title: Enable coded Phy

children.help:
Change this option to set maximum number of extended advertising
instances. Minimum there is always one instance of
advertising. Enter how many more advertising instances you
want.
For ESP32C2, ESP32C6 and ESP32H2, each extended advertising instance
will take about 0.5k DRAM.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MAX_EXT_ADV_INSTANCES
children.title: Maximum number of extended advertising instances.

children.help:
Defines the length of the extended adv data. The value should not
exceed 1650.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_EXT_ADV_MAX_SIZE
children.title: Maximum length of the advertising data.

children.help: This enables controller transfer periodic sync events to host
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_PERIODIC_ADV_SYNC_TRANSFER
children.title: Enable Transer Sync Events

children.help: Enable this option to start periodic advertisement.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_ENABLE_PERIODIC_ADV
children.title: Enable periodic advertisement.

children.help:
Enable this option to do extended advertising. Extended advertising
will be supported from BLE 5.0 onwards.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_EXT_ADV
children.title: Enable extended advertising

children.help:
Set this option to set the upper limit for number of periodic sync
connections. This should be less than maximum connections allowed by
controller.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MAX_PERIODIC_SYNCS
children.title: Maximum number of periodic advertising syncs

children.help: Set this option to set the upper limit for number of periodic advertiser list.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_MAX_PERIODIC_ADVERTISER_LIST
children.title: Maximum number of periodic advertiser list

children.help: Set this option to enable the Power Control feature
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_BLE_POWER_CONTROL
children.title: Enable support for BLE Power Control

children.help: Enable BLE 5 feature
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_50_FEATURE_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable BLE 5 feature

children.help: Always enable the limitation on max tx/rx time for Coded-PHY connection
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_COEX_PHY_CODED_TX_RX_TLIM_EN
children.title: Force Enable

children.help: Disable the limitation on max tx/rx time for Coded-PHY connection
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_COEX_PHY_CODED_TX_RX_TLIM_DIS
children.title: Force Disable

children.help:
When using PHY-Coded in BLE connection, limitation on max tx/rx time can be applied to
better avoid dramatic performance deterioration of Wi-Fi.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_COEX_PHY_CODED_TX_RX_TLIM
children.title: Coexistence: limit on MAX Tx/Rx time for coded-PHY connection

children.help: BLE list size
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_WHITELIST_SIZE
children.title: BLE white list size

children.help: Enable the throughput test mode
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_TEST_THROUGHPUT_TEST
children.title: Throughput Test Mode enable

children.help: Set this option to enable blufi functionality.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_BLUFI_ENABLE
children.title: Enable blufi functionality

children.help: Set this option to use Esp Timer which has higher priority timer instead of FreeRTOS timer
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_USE_ESP_TIMER
children.title: Enable Esp Timer for Nimble

children.help: This option is used to distinguish whether a previous version of VHCI is being used
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_LEGACY_VHCI_ENABLE

children.help:
This option is used when data to be sent is more than 512 bytes. For peripheral role,
BT_NIMBLE_MSYS_1_BLOCK_COUNT needs to be increased according to the need.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_BLE_GATT_BLOB_TRANSFER
children.title: Blob transfer

children.help:
This option is used to enable support for sending Vendor Specific HCI commands and handling
Vendor Specific HCI Events.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_VS_SUPPORT
children.title: Enable support for VSC and VSE

children.help:
This option enables the use of vendor-specific APIs for multi-connections, which can
greatly enhance the stability of coexistence between numerous central and peripheral
devices. It will prohibit the usage of standard APIs.
children.name: BT_NIMBLE_OPTIMIZE_MULTI_CONN
children.title: Enable the optimization of multi-connection

children.help:
BLE maximum activities of bluetooth controller，both of connections,
scan , sync and adv(periodic adv, multi-adv). Each instance needs to
consume 828 bytes, you can save RAM by modifying the instance value
according to actual needs.
children.name: BT_CTRL_BLE_MAX_ACT
children.title: BLE Max Instances

children.help:
BLE ACL buffer have two methods to be allocated. One is persistent allocating
(alloate when controller initialise, never free until controller de-initialise)
another is dynamically allocating (allocate before TX and free after TX).
children.name: BT_CTRL_BLE_STATIC_ACL_TX_BUF_NB
children.title: BLE static ACL TX buffer numbers

children.help:
Specify the cpu core to run bluetooth controller.
Can not specify no-affinity.
children.name: BT_CTRL_PINNED_TO_CORE_CHOICE
children.title: The cpu core which bluetooth controller run

children.help: Normal option. Mostly, choose this VHCI when bluetooth host run on ESP32S3 or ESP32C3.
children.name: BT_CTRL_HCI_MODE_VHCI
children.title: VHCI

children.help:
If use external bluetooth host which run on other hardware and use UART as the HCI interface,
choose this option.
children.name: BT_CTRL_HCI_MODE_UART_H4
children.title: UART(H4)

children.help: Specify HCI mode as VHCI or UART(H4)
children.name: BT_CTRL_HCI_MODE_CHOICE
children.title: HCI mode

children.help: HCI mode as VHCI or UART(H4)
children.name: BT_CTRL_HCI_TL

children.help: The maxinum number of suplicate scan filter
children.name: BT_CTRL_ADV_DUP_FILT_MAX
children.title: The maxinum number of 5.0 extend duplicate scan filter

children.help: It enables HW CCA feature in controller
children.name: BT_CTRL_HW_CCA
children.title: HW CCA check enable

children.help: It is the threshold value of HW CCA, if the value is 30, it means CCA threshold is -30 dBm.
children.name: BT_CTRL_HW_CCA_VAL
children.title: CCA threshold value

children.help:
If other devices are sending packets in the air and the signal is strong,
the packet hw to be sent this time is cancelled.
children.name: BT_CTRL_HW_CCA_EFF
BT_CTRL_CE_LENGTH_TYPE_CE
children.title: Use CE parameter for HCI command

children.help: Specify connection event length determination
children.name: BT_CTRL_CE_LENGTH_TYPE
children.title: Connection event length determination method

children.help: Specify default Tx antenna used for bluetooth
children.name: BT_CTRL_TX_ANTENNA_INDEX
children.title: default Tx anntena used

children.help: Specify default Rx antenna used for bluetooth
children.name: BT_CTRL_RX_ANTENNA_INDEX
children.title: default Rx anntena used

children.help: Specify default Tx power level
children.name: BT_CTRL_DFT_TX_POWER_LEVEL
children.title: BLE default Tx power level

children.help:
The number of unprocessed advertising report that bluetooth host can save.If you set
`BT_CTRL_BLE_ADV_REPORT_FLOW_CTRL_NUM` to a small value, this may cause adv packets lost.
If you set `BT_CTRL_BLE_ADV_REPORT_FLOW_CTRL_NUM` to a large value, bluetooth host may cache a
lot of adv packets and this may cause system memory run out. For example, if you set
it to 50, the maximum memory consumed by host is 35 * 50 bytes. Please set
`BT_CTRL_BLE_ADV_REPORT_FLOW_CTRL_NUM` according to your system free memory and handle adv
packets as fast as possible, otherwise it will cause adv packets lost.
children.name: BT_CTRL_BLE_ADV_REPORT_FLOW_CTRL_NUM
children.title: BLE adv report flow control number

children.help:
When adv report flow control is enabled, The ADV lost event will be generated when the number
of ADV packets lost in the controller reaches this threshold. It is better to set a larger value.
If you set `BT_CTRL_BLE_ADV_REPORT_DISCARD_THRSHOLD` to a small value or printf every adv lost event, it
may cause adv packets lost more.
children.name: BT_CTRL_BLE_ADV_REPORT_DISCARD_THRSHOLD
children.title: BLE adv lost event threshold value

children.help:
The function is mainly used to enable flow control for advertising reports. When it is enabled,
advertising reports will be discarded by the controller if the number of unprocessed advertising
reports exceeds the size of BLE adv report flow control.
children.name: BT_CTRL_BLE_ADV_REPORT_FLOW_CTRL_SUPP
children.title: BLE adv report flow control supported

children.help:
This way is to use advertiser address filtering. The adv packet of the same address is only
allowed to be reported once
children.name: BT_CTRL_SCAN_DUPL_TYPE_DEVICE
children.title: Scan Duplicate By Device Address

children.help:
This way is to use advertising data filtering. All same advertising data only allow to be reported
once even though they are from different devices.
children.name: BT_CTRL_SCAN_DUPL_TYPE_DATA
children.title: Scan Duplicate By Advertising Data

children.help:
This way is to use advertising data and device address filtering. All different adv packets with
the same address are allowed to be reported.
children.name: BT_CTRL_SCAN_DUPL_TYPE_DATA_DEVICE
children.title: Scan Duplicate By Device Address And Advertising Data

children.help:
Scan duplicate have three ways. one is "Scan Duplicate By Device Address", This way is to use
advertiser address filtering. The adv packet of the same address is only allowed to be reported once.
Another way is "Scan Duplicate By Device Address And Advertising Data". This way is to use advertising
data and device address filtering. All different adv packets with the same address are allowed to be
reported. The last way is "Scan Duplicate By Advertising Data". This way is to use advertising data
filtering. All same advertising data only allow to be reported once even though they are from
different devices.
children.name: BT_CTRL_SCAN_DUPL_TYPE
children.title: Scan Duplicate Type

children.help:
Maximum number of devices which can be recorded in scan duplicate filter.
When the maximum amount of device in the filter is reached, the cache will be refreshed.
children.name: BT_CTRL_SCAN_DUPL_CACHE_SIZE
children.title: Maximum number of devices in scan duplicate filter

children.help:
If the period value is non-zero, the controller will periodically clear the device information
stored in the scan duuplicate filter. If it is 0, the scan duuplicate filter will not be cleared
until the scanning is disabled. Duplicate advertisements for this period should not be sent to the
Host in advertising report events.
There are two scenarios where the ADV packet will be repeatedly reported:
1. The duplicate scan cache is full, the controller will delete the oldest device information and
add new device information.
2. When the refresh period is up, the controller will clear all device information and start filtering
again.
children.name: BT_CTRL_DUPL_SCAN_CACHE_REFRESH_PERIOD
children.title: Duplicate scan list refresh period (seconds)

children.help:
Maximum number of adv packets which can be recorded in duplicate scan cache for BLE Mesh.
When the maximum amount of device in the filter is reached, the cache will be refreshed.
children.name: BT_CTRL_MESH_DUPL_SCAN_CACHE_SIZE
children.title: Maximum number of Mesh adv packets in scan duplicate filter

children.help: This enables the BLE scan duplicate for special BLE Mesh scan.
children.name: BT_CTRL_BLE_MESH_SCAN_DUPL_EN
children.title: Special duplicate scan mechanism for BLE Mesh scan

children.help: This select enables parameters setting of BLE scan duplicate.
children.name: BT_CTRL_BLE_SCAN_DUPL
children.title: BLE Scan Duplicate Options

children.help: Always enable the limitation on max tx/rx time for Coded-PHY connection
children.name: BT_CTRL_COEX_PHY_CODED_TX_RX_TLIM_EN
children.title: Force Enable

children.help: Disable the limitation on max tx/rx time for Coded-PHY connection
children.name: BT_CTRL_COEX_PHY_CODED_TX_RX_TLIM_DIS
children.title: Force Disable

children.help:
When using PHY-Coded in BLE connection, limitation on max tx/rx time can be applied to
better avoid dramatic performance deterioration of Wi-Fi.
children.name: BT_CTRL_COEX_PHY_CODED_TX_RX_TLIM
children.title: Coexistence: limit on MAX Tx/Rx time for coded-PHY connection

children.help:
Main crystal can be used as low power clock for bluetooth modem sleep. If this option is
selected, bluetooth modem sleep can work under Dynamic Frequency Scaling(DFS) enabled, and
bluetooth can work under light sleep enabled. Main crystal has a relatively better performance
than other bluetooth low power clock sources.
children.name: BT_CTRL_LPCLK_SEL_MAIN_XTAL
children.title: Main crystal

children.help:
External 32kHz crystal has a nominal frequency of 32.768kHz and provides good frequency
stability. If used as Bluetooth low power clock, External 32kHz can support Bluetooth
modem sleep to be used with both DFS and light sleep.
children.name: BT_CTRL_LPCLK_SEL_EXT_32K_XTAL
children.title: External 32kHz crystal

children.help:
Internal 150kHz RC oscillator. The accuracy of this clock is a lot larger than 500ppm which is required
in Bluetooth communication, so don't select this option in scenarios such as BLE connection state.
children.name: BT_CTRL_LPCLK_SEL_RTC_SLOW
children.title: Internal 150kHz RC oscillator

children.help: Select the low power clock source for bluetooth controller
children.name: BT_CTRL_LOW_POWER_CLOCK
children.title: Bluetooth low power clock

children.help:
Mode 1 is the currently supported sleep mode. In this mode,
bluetooth controller sleeps between and BLE events. A low
power clock is used to maintain bluetooth reference clock.
children.name: BT_CTRL_MODEM_SLEEP_MODE_1
children.title: Bluetooth Modem sleep Mode 1

children.help:
Enable/disable bluetooth controller low power mode.
Modem sleep is not supported to be used with UART HCI.
children.name: BT_CTRL_MODEM_SLEEP
children.title: Bluetooth modem sleep

children.help:
If this option is selected, the main crystal will power up during light sleep when the low power clock
selects an external 32kHz crystal but the external 32kHz crystal does not exist or the low power clock
selects the main crystal.
children.name: BT_CTRL_MAIN_XTAL_PU_DURING_LIGHT_SLEEP
children.title: power up main XTAL during light sleep

children.help: Enable coded phy AGC recorrect
children.name: BT_CTRL_CODED_AGC_RECORRECT_EN
children.title: Enable coded phy AGC recorrect

children.help: Enable uncoded phy AGC recorrect
children.name: BT_CTRL_AGC_RECORRECT_EN
children.title: Enable HW AGC recorrect

children.help:
Disable active scan backoff. The bluetooth spec requires that scanners should run a backoff procedure to
minimize collision of scan request PDUs from nultiple scanners. If scan backoff is disabled, in active
scanning, scan request PDU will be sent every time when HW receives scannable ADV PDU.
children.name: BT_CTRL_SCAN_BACKOFF_UPPERLIMITMAX
children.title: Disable active scan backoff

children.help: It is a temporary solution and needs further modifications.
children.name: BLE_MESH_HCI_5_0
children.title: Support sending 20ms non-connectable adv packets

children.help:
Enable this option to allow using specific duplicate scan filter
in BLE Mesh, and Scan Duplicate Type must be set by choosing the
option in the Bluetooth Controller section in menuconfig, which is
"Scan Duplicate By Device Address and Advertising Data".
children.name: BLE_MESH_USE_DUPLICATE_SCAN
children.title: Support Duplicate Scan in BLE Mesh

children.help:
Enable this option to use the default memory allocation strategy when
external SPIRAM is enabled. See the SPIRAM options for more details.
children.name: BLE_MESH_MEM_ALLOC_MODE_DEFAULT
children.title: Default alloc mode

children.help:
Allows to use IRAM memory region as 8bit accessible region. Every
unaligned (8bit or 16bit) access will result in an exception and
incur penalty of certain clock cycles per unaligned read/write.
children.name: BLE_MESH_MEM_ALLOC_MODE_IRAM_8BIT
children.title: Internal IRAM

children.help:
Allocation strategy for BLE Mesh stack, essentially provides ability to
allocate all required dynamic allocations from,

- Internal DRAM memory only
- External SPIRAM memory only
- Either internal or external memory based on default malloc()
  behavior in ESP-IDF
- Internal IRAM memory wherever applicable else internal DRAM

Recommended mode here is always internal (*), since that is most preferred
from security perspective. But if application requirement does not
allow sufficient free internal memory then alternate mode can be
selected.

(*) In case of ESP32-S2/ESP32-S3, hardware allows encryption of external
SPIRAM contents provided hardware flash encryption feature is enabled.
In that case, using external SPIRAM allocation strategy is also safe choice
from security perspective.
children.name: BLE_MESH_MEM_ALLOC_MODE
children.title: Memory allocation strategy

children.help:
If enabled, BLE Mesh allocates dynamic memory from external SPIRAM for
FreeRTOS objects, i.e. mutex, queue, and task stack. External SPIRAM
can only be used for task stack when SPIRAM_ALLOW_STACK_EXTERNAL_MEMORY
is enabled. See the SPIRAM options for more details.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FREERTOS_STATIC_ALLOC_EXTERNAL
children.title: External SPIRAM

children.help:
If enabled, BLE Mesh allocates dynamic memory from internal IRAM for
FreeRTOS objects, i.e. mutex, queue. Note: IRAM region cannot be used
as task stack.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FREERTOS_STATIC_ALLOC_IRAM_8BIT
children.title: Internal IRAM

children.help: Choose the memory to be used for FreeRTOS objects.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FREERTOS_STATIC_ALLOC_MODE
children.title: Memory allocation for FreeRTOS objects

children.help:
Enable this option to use FreeRTOS static allocation APIs for BLE Mesh,
which provides the ability to use different dynamic memory (i.e. SPIRAM
or IRAM) for FreeRTOS objects.
If this option is disabled, the FreeRTOS static allocation APIs will not
be used, and internal DRAM will be allocated for FreeRTOS objects.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FREERTOS_STATIC_ALLOC
children.title: Enable FreeRTOS static allocation

children.help:
If enabled, users can use the function esp_ble_mesh_deinit() to de-initialize
the whole BLE Mesh stack.
children.name: BLE_MESH_DEINIT
children.title: Support de-initialize BLE Mesh stack

children.help: Number of advertising buffers for BLE packets available.
children.name: BLE_MESH_BLE_ADV_BUF_COUNT
children.title: Number of advertising buffers for BLE advertising packets

children.help:
When selected, users can send normal BLE advertising packets
with specific API.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SUPPORT_BLE_ADV
children.title: Support sending normal BLE advertising packets

children.help:
When selected, users can register a callback and receive normal BLE
advertising packets in the application layer.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SUPPORT_BLE_SCAN
children.title: Support scanning normal BLE advertising packets
BLE Mesh and BLE coexistence support

children.help:
Enable this option to allow BLE Mesh fast provisioning solution to be used.
When there are multiple unprovisioned devices around, fast provisioning can
greatly reduce the time consumption of the whole provisioning process.
When this option is enabled, and after an unprovisioned device is provisioned
into a node successfully, it can be changed to a temporary Provisioner.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FAST_PROV
children.title: Enable BLE Mesh Fast Provisioning

children.help:
Enable the device to be provisioned into a node. This option should be
enabled when an unprovisioned device is going to be provisioned into a
node and communicate with other nodes in the BLE Mesh network.
children.name: BLE_MESH_NODE
children.title: Support for BLE Mesh Node

children.help:
This option specifies how many unprovisioned devices can be added to device
queue for provisioning. Users can use this option to define the size of the
queue in the bottom layer which is used to store unprovisioned device
information (e.g. Device UUID, address).
children.name: BLE_MESH_WAIT_FOR_PROV_MAX_DEV_NUM
children.title: Maximum number of unprovisioned devices that can be added to device queue

children.help:
This option specifies how many devices can be provisioned by a Provisioner.
This value indicates the maximum number of unprovisioned devices which can be
provisioned by a Provisioner. For instance, if the value is 6, it means the
Provisioner can provision up to 6 unprovisioned devices.
Theoretically a Provisioner without the limitation of its memory can provision
up to 32766 unprovisioned devices, here we limit the maximum number to 100
just to limit the memory used by a Provisioner. The bigger the value is, the
more memory it will cost by a Provisioner to store the information of nodes.
children.name: BLE_MESH_MAX_PROV_NODES
children.title: Maximum number of devices that can be provisioned by Provisioner

children.help:
This option specifies how many devices can be provisioned at the same time
using PB-ADV. For examples, if the value is 2, it means a Provisioner can
provision two unprovisioned devices with PB-ADV at the same time.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PBA_SAME_TIME
children.title: Maximum number of PB-ADV running at the same time by Provisioner

children.help:
This option specifies how many devices can be provisioned at the same
time using PB-GATT. For example, if the value is 2, it means a Provisioner
can provision two unprovisioned devices with PB-GATT at the same time.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PBG_SAME_TIME
children.title: Maximum number of PB-GATT running at the same time by Provisioner

children.help:
This option specifies how many subnets per network a Provisioner can create.
Indeed, this value decides the number of network keys which can be added by a Provisioner.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PROVISIONER_SUBNET_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of mesh subnets that can be created by Provisioner

children.help:
This option specifies how many application keys the Provisioner can have.
Indeed, this value decides the number of the application keys which can be added by a Provisioner.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PROVISIONER_APP_KEY_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of application keys that can be owned by Provisioner

children.help:
This option specifies how many heartbeat filter entries Provisioner supports.
The heartbeat filter (acceptlist or rejectlist) entries are used to store a
list of SRC and DST which can be used to decide if a heartbeat message will
be processed and notified to the application layer by Provisioner.
Note: The filter is an empty rejectlist by default.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PROVISIONER_RECV_HB_FILTER_SIZE
children.title: Maximum number of filter entries for receiving Heartbeat messages

children.help:
When this option is enabled, Provisioner can call specific functions to enable
or disable receiving Heartbeat messages and notify them to the application layer.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PROVISIONER_RECV_HB
children.title: Support receiving Heartbeat messages

children.help:
Enable the device to be a Provisioner. The option should be enabled when
a device is going to act as a Provisioner and provision unprovisioned
devices into the BLE Mesh network.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PROVISIONER
children.title: Support for BLE Mesh Provisioner

children.help:
Enable this option to support BLE Mesh Provisioning functionality. For
BLE Mesh, this option should be always enabled.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PROV
children.title: BLE Mesh Provisioning support

children.help:
This option specifies the interval of sending two consecutive unprovisioned
device beacon, users can use this option to change the frequency of sending
unprovisioned device beacon. For example, if the value is 5, it means the
unprovisioned device beacon will send every 5 seconds. When the option of
BLE_MESH_FAST_PROV is selected, the value is better to be 3 seconds, or less.
children.name: BLE_MESH_UNPROVISIONED_BEACON_INTERVAL
children.title: Interval between two consecutive Unprovisioned Device Beacon

children.help:
Enable this option to allow the device to be provisioned over the
advertising bearer. This option should be enabled if PB-ADV is
going to be used during provisioning procedure.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PB_ADV
children.title: Provisioning support using the advertising bearer (PB-ADV)

children.help:
Enable this option to allow the device to be provisioned over GATT.
This option should be enabled if PB-GATT is going to be used during
provisioning procedure.

# Virtual option enabled whenever any Proxy protocol is needed
children.name: BLE_MESH_PB_GATT
children.title: Provisioning support using GATT (PB-GATT)

children.help:
Enable this option to support BLE Mesh Proxy protocol used by PB-GATT
and other proxy pdu transmission.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PROXY
children.title: BLE Mesh Proxy protocol support

children.help:
This option determines for how long the local node advertises using
Node Identity. The given value is in seconds. The specification limits
this to 60 seconds and lists it as the recommended value as well.
So leaving the default value is the safest option.
When an unprovisioned device is provisioned successfully and becomes a
node, it will start to advertise using Node Identity during the time
set by this option. And after that, Network ID will be advertised.
children.name: BLE_MESH_NODE_ID_TIMEOUT
children.title: Node Identity advertising timeout

children.help:
This option specifies how many Proxy Filter entries the local node supports.
The entries of Proxy filter (whitelist or blacklist) are used to store a
list of addresses which can be used to decide which messages will be forwarded
to the Proxy Client by the Proxy Server.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PROXY_FILTER_SIZE
children.title: Maximum number of filter entries per Proxy Client

children.help:
This option enables support for Mesh GATT Proxy Service, i.e. the
ability to act as a proxy between a Mesh GATT Client and a Mesh network.
This option should be enabled if a node is going to be a Proxy Server.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GATT_PROXY_SERVER
children.title: BLE Mesh GATT Proxy Server

children.help:
This option enables support for Mesh GATT Proxy Client. The Proxy Client
can use the GATT bearer to send mesh messages to a node that supports the
advertising bearer.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GATT_PROXY_CLIENT
children.title: BLE Mesh GATT Proxy Client

children.help:
Enable BLE Mesh net buffer pool tracking. This option is used to introduce another
variable in the bottom layer to record the usage of advertising buffers of BLE Mesh
devices. Recommend to enable this option as default.
children.name: BLE_MESH_NET_BUF_POOL_USAGE

children.help:
This value defines in seconds how soon any pending changes are actually
written into persistent storage (flash) after a change occurs.
The option allows nodes to delay a certain period of time to save proper
information to flash. The default value is 0, which means information
will be stored immediately once there are updates.
children.name: BLE_MESH_STORE_TIMEOUT
children.title: Delay (in seconds) before storing anything persistently

children.help:
This value defines how often the local sequence number gets updated in
persistent storage (i.e. flash). e.g. a value of 100 means that the
sequence number will be stored to flash on every 100th increment.
If the node sends messages very frequently a higher value makes more
sense, whereas if the node sends infrequently a value as low as 0
(update storage for every increment) can make sense. When the stack
gets initialized it will add sequence number to the last stored one,
so that it starts off with a value that's guaranteed to be larger than
the last one used before power off.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SEQ_STORE_RATE
children.title: How often the sequence number gets updated in storage

children.help:
This value defines in seconds how soon the RPL (Replay Protection List)
gets written to persistent storage after a change occurs. If the node
receives messages frequently, then a large value is recommended. If the
node receives messages rarely, then the value can be as low as 0 (which
means the RPL is written into the storage immediately).
Note that if the node operates in a security-sensitive case, and there is
a risk of sudden power-off, then a value of 0 is strongly recommended.
Otherwise, a power loss before RPL being written into the storage may
introduce message replay attacks and system security will be in a
vulnerable state.
children.name: BLE_MESH_RPL_STORE_TIMEOUT
children.title: Minimum frequency that the RPL gets updated in storage

children.help:
This option is created to solve the issue of failure in recovering
node information after mesh stack updates. In the old version mesh
stack, there is no key of "mesh/role" in nvs. In the new version
mesh stack, key of "mesh/role" is added in nvs, recovering node
information needs to check "mesh/role" key in nvs and implements
selective recovery of mesh node information. Therefore, there may
be failure in recovering node information during node restarting
after OTA.

The new version mesh stack adds the option of "mesh/role" because
we have added the support of storing Provisioner information, while
the old version only supports storing node information.

If users are updating their nodes from old version to new version,
we recommend enabling this option, so that system could set the flag
in advance before recovering node information and make sure the node
information recovering could work as expected.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SETTINGS_BACKWARD_COMPATIBILITY
children.title: A specific option for settings backward compatibility

children.help:
This value defines the name of the specified NVS partition used by the
mesh stack.
children.name: BLE_MESH_PARTITION_NAME
children.title: Name of the NVS partition for BLE Mesh

children.help:
When selected, the mesh stack will use a specified NVS partition instead of
default NVS partition. Note that the specified partition must be registered
with NVS using nvs_flash_init_partition() API, and the partition must exists
in the csv file.
When Provisioner needs to store a large amount of nodes' information in the
flash (e.g. more than 20), this option is recommended to be enabled.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SPECIFIC_PARTITION
children.title: Use a specific NVS partition for BLE Mesh

children.help: This option specifies the maximum NVS namespaces supported by Provisioner.
children.name: BLE_MESH_MAX_NVS_NAMESPACE
children.title: Maximum number of NVS namespaces

children.help:
When selected, Provisioner can use different NVS namespaces to store
different instances of mesh information.
For example, if in the first room, Provisioner uses NetKey A, AppKey
A and provisions three devices, these information will be treated as
mesh information instance A. When the Provisioner moves to the second
room, it uses NetKey B, AppKey B and provisions two devices, then the
information will be treated as mesh information instance B.
Here instance A and instance B will be stored in different namespaces.
With this option enabled, Provisioner needs to use specific functions
to open the corresponding NVS namespace, restore the mesh information,
release the mesh information or erase the mesh information.
children.name: BLE_MESH_USE_MULTIPLE_NAMESPACE
children.title: Support using multiple NVS namespaces by Provisioner

children.help:
When selected, the BLE Mesh stack will take care of storing/restoring the BLE
Mesh configuration persistently in flash.
If the device is a BLE Mesh node, when this option is enabled, the configuration
of the device will be stored persistently, including unicast address, NetKey,
AppKey, etc.
And if the device is a BLE Mesh Provisioner, the information of the device will
be stored persistently, including the information of provisioned nodes, NetKey,
AppKey, etc.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SETTINGS
children.title: Store BLE Mesh configuration persistently

children.help:
This option specifies how many subnets a Mesh network can have at the same time.
Indeed, this value decides the number of the network keys which can be owned by a node.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SUBNET_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of mesh subnets per network

children.help:
This option specifies how many application keys the device can store per network.
Indeed, this value decides the number of the application keys which can be owned by a node.
children.name: BLE_MESH_APP_KEY_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of application keys per network

children.help:
This option specifies the maximum number of application keys to which each model
can be bound.
children.name: BLE_MESH_MODEL_KEY_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of application keys per model

children.help:
This option specifies the maximum number of addresses to which each model can
be subscribed.
children.name: BLE_MESH_MODEL_GROUP_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of group address subscriptions per model

children.help:
This option specifies how many Label UUIDs can be stored.
Indeed, this value decides the number of the Virtual Addresses can be supported by a node.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LABEL_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of Label UUIDs used for Virtual Addresses

children.help:
This option specifies the maximum capacity of the replay protection list.
It is similar to Network message cache size, but has a different purpose.
The replay protection list is used to prevent a node from replay attack,
which will store the source address and sequence number of the received
mesh messages.
For Provisioner, the replay protection list size should not be smaller than
the maximum number of nodes whose information can be stored. And the element
number of each node should also be taken into consideration. For example, if
Provisioner can provision up to 20 nodes and each node contains two elements,
then the replay protection list size of Provisioner should be at least 40.
children.name: BLE_MESH_CRPL
children.title: Maximum capacity of the replay protection list

children.help:
Number of messages that are cached for the network. This helps prevent
unnecessary decryption operations and unnecessary relays. This option
is similar to Replay protection list, but has a different purpose.
A node is not required to cache the entire Network PDU and may cache
only part of it for tracking, such as values for SRC/SEQ or others.
children.name: BLE_MESH_MSG_CACHE_SIZE
children.title: Network message cache size

children.help:
Number of advertising buffers available. The transport layer reserves
ADV_BUF_COUNT - 3 buffers for outgoing segments. The maximum outgoing
SDU size is 12 times this value (out of which 4 or 8 bytes are used
for the Transport Layer MIC). For example, 5 segments means the maximum
SDU size is 60 bytes, which leaves 56 bytes for application layer data
using a 4-byte MIC, or 52 bytes using an 8-byte MIC.
children.name: BLE_MESH_ADV_BUF_COUNT
children.title: Number of advertising buffers

children.help:
When the IV Update state enters Normal operation or IV Update
in Progress, we need to keep track of how many hours has passed
in the state, since the specification requires us to remain in
the state at least for 96 hours (Update in Progress has an
additional upper limit of 144 hours).

In order to fulfill the above requirement, even if the node might
be powered off once in a while, we need to store persistently
how many hours the node has been in the state. This doesn't
necessarily need to happen every hour (thanks to the flexible
duration range). The exact cadence will depend a lot on the
ways that the node will be used and what kind of power source it
has.

Since there is no single optimal answer, this configuration
option allows specifying a divider, i.e. how many intervals
the 96 hour minimum gets split into. After each interval the
duration that the node has been in the current state gets
stored to flash. E.g. the default value of 4 means that the
state is saved every 24 hours (96 / 4).
children.name: BLE_MESH_IVU_DIVIDER
children.title: Divider for IV Update state refresh timer

children.help:
According to Section 3.10.5 of Mesh Specification v1.0.1.
If a node in Normal Operation receives a Secure Network beacon with an IV index
equal to the last known IV index+1 and the IV Update Flag set to 0, the node may
update its IV without going to the IV Update in Progress state, or it may initiate
an IV Index Recovery procedure (Section 3.10.6), or it may ignore the Secure
Network beacon. The node makes the choice depending on the time since last IV
update and the likelihood that the node has missed the Secure Network beacons
with the IV update Flag.
When the above situation is encountered, this option can be used to decide whether
to perform the IV index recovery procedure.
children.name: BLE_MESH_IVU_RECOVERY_IVI
children.title: Recovery the IV index when the latest whole IV update procedure is missed

children.help:
Maximum number of simultaneous outgoing multi-segment and/or reliable messages.
The default value is 1, which means the device can only send one segmented
message at a time. And if another segmented message is going to be sent, it
should wait for the completion of the previous one.
If users are going to send multiple segmented messages at the same time, this
value should be configured properly.
children.name: BLE_MESH_TX_SEG_MSG_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of simultaneous outgoing segmented messages

children.help:
Maximum number of simultaneous incoming multi-segment and/or reliable messages.
The default value is 1, which means the device can only receive one segmented
message at a time. And if another segmented message is going to be received,
it should wait for the completion of the previous one.
If users are going to receive multiple segmented messages at the same time, this
value should be configured properly.
children.name: BLE_MESH_RX_SEG_MSG_COUNT
children.title: Maximum number of simultaneous incoming segmented messages

children.help:
Maximum incoming Upper Transport Access PDU length. Leave this to the default
value, unless you really need to optimize memory usage.
children.name: BLE_MESH_RX_SDU_MAX
children.title: Maximum incoming Upper Transport Access PDU length

children.help:
Maximum number of segments supported for outgoing messages.
This value should typically be fine-tuned based on what
models the local node supports, i.e. what's the largest
message payload that the node needs to be able to send.
This value affects memory and call stack consumption, which
is why the default is lower than the maximum that the
specification would allow (32 segments).

The maximum outgoing SDU size is 12 times this number (out of
which 4 or 8 bytes is used for the Transport Layer MIC). For
example, 5 segments means the maximum SDU size is 60 bytes,
which leaves 56 bytes for application layer data using a
4-byte MIC and 52 bytes using an 8-byte MIC.

Be sure to specify a sufficient number of advertising buffers
when setting this option to a higher value. There must be at
least three more advertising buffers (BLE_MESH_ADV_BUF_COUNT)
as there are outgoing segments.
children.name: BLE_MESH_TX_SEG_MAX
children.title: Maximum number of segments in outgoing messages

children.help: Number of advertising buffers for relay packets available.
children.name: BLE_MESH_RELAY_ADV_BUF_COUNT
children.title: Number of advertising buffers for relay packets

children.help:
When selected, self-send packets will be put in a high-priority
queue and relay packets will be put in a low-priority queue.
children.name: BLE_MESH_RELAY_ADV_BUF
children.title: Use separate advertising buffers for relay packets

children.help:
Support for acting as a Mesh Relay Node. Enabling this option will allow
a node to support the Relay feature, and the Relay feature can still
be enabled or disabled by proper configuration messages. Disabling this
option will let a node not support the Relay feature.
children.name: BLE_MESH_RELAY
children.title: Relay support

children.help:
Perform the Friendship establishment using low power with the help of a
reduced scan duty cycle. The downside of this is that the node may miss
out on messages intended for it until it has successfully set up Friendship
with a Friend node.
When this option is enabled, the node will stop scanning for a period of
time after a Friend Request or Friend Poll is sent, so as to reduce more
power consumption.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_ESTABLISHMENT
children.title: Perform Friendship establishment using low power

children.help:
Time in seconds from the last received message, that the node waits out
before starting to look for Friend nodes.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_AUTO_TIMEOUT
children.title: Time from last received message before going to LPN mode

children.help:
Once provisioned, automatically enable LPN functionality and start looking
for Friend nodes. If this option is disabled LPN mode needs to be manually
enabled by calling bt_mesh_lpn_set(true).
When an unprovisioned device is provisioned successfully and becomes a node,
enabling this option will trigger the node starts to send Friend Request at
a certain period until it finds a proper Friend node.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_AUTO
children.title: Automatically start looking for Friend nodes once provisioned

children.help:
Time in seconds between Friend Requests, if a previous Friend Request did
not yield any acceptable Friend Offers.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_RETRY_TIMEOUT
children.title: Retry timeout for Friend requests

children.help:
The contribution of the RSSI, measured by the Friend node, used in Friend
Offer Delay calculations. 0 = 1, 1 = 1.5, 2 = 2, 3 = 2.5.
RSSIFactor, one of the parameters carried by Friend Request sent by Low Power
node, which is used to calculate the Friend Offer Delay.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_RSSI_FACTOR
children.title: RSSIFactor, used in Friend Offer Delay calculation

children.help:
The contribution of the supported Receive Window used in Friend Offer
Delay calculations. 0 = 1, 1 = 1.5, 2 = 2, 3 = 2.5.
ReceiveWindowFactor, one of the parameters carried by Friend Request sent by
Low Power node, which is used to calculate the Friend Offer Delay.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_RECV_WIN_FACTOR
children.title: ReceiveWindowFactor, used in Friend Offer Delay calculation

children.help:
The MinQueueSizeLog field is defined as log_2(N), where N is the minimum
number of maximum size Lower Transport PDUs that the Friend node can store
in its Friend Queue. As an example, MinQueueSizeLog value 1 gives N = 2,
and value 7 gives N = 128.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_MIN_QUEUE_SIZE
children.title: Minimum size of the acceptable friend queue (MinQueueSizeLog)

children.help:
The ReceiveDelay is the time between the Low Power node sending a
request and listening for a response. This delay allows the Friend
node time to prepare the response. The value is in units of milliseconds.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_RECV_DELAY
children.title: Receive delay requested by the local node

children.help:
PollTimeout timer is used to measure time between two consecutive
requests sent by a Low Power node. If no requests are received
the Friend node before the PollTimeout timer expires, then the
friendship is considered terminated. The value is in units of 100
milliseconds, so e.g. a value of 300 means 30 seconds.
The smaller the value, the faster the Low Power node tries to get
messages from corresponding Friend node and vice versa.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_POLL_TIMEOUT
children.title: The value of the PollTimeout timer

children.help:
The initial value of the PollTimeout timer when Friendship is to be
established for the first time. After this, the timeout gradually
grows toward the actual PollTimeout, doubling in value for each iteration.
The value is in units of 100 milliseconds, so e.g. a value of 300 means
30 seconds.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_INIT_POLL_TIMEOUT
children.title: The starting value of the PollTimeout timer

children.help:
Latency (in milliseconds) is the time it takes to enable scanning. In
practice, it means how much time in advance of the Receive Window, the
request to enable scanning is made.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_SCAN_LATENCY
children.title: Latency for enabling scanning

children.help: Maximum number of groups to which the LPN can subscribe.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_GROUPS
children.title: Number of groups the LPN can subscribe to

children.help:
Automatically subscribe all nodes address when friendship
established.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LPN_SUB_ALL_NODES_ADDR
children.title: Automatically subscribe all nodes address

children.help:
Enable this option to operate as a Low Power Node. If low power consumption
is required by a node, this option should be enabled. And once the node
enters the mesh network, it will try to find a Friend node and establish a
friendship.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LOW_POWER
children.title: Support for Low Power features

children.help: Receive Window in milliseconds supported by the Friend node.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FRIEND_RECV_WIN
children.title: Friend Receive Window

children.help:
Minimum number of buffers available to be stored for each local Friend Queue.
This option decides the size of each buffer which can be used by a Friend node
to store messages for each Low Power node.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FRIEND_QUEUE_SIZE
children.title: Minimum number of buffers supported per Friend Queue

children.help:
Size of the Subscription List that can be supported by a Friend node for a
Low Power node. And Low Power node can send Friend Subscription List Add or
Friend Subscription List Remove messages to the Friend node to add or remove
subscription addresses.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FRIEND_SUB_LIST_SIZE
children.title: Friend Subscription List Size

children.help:
Number of Low Power Nodes with which a Friend can have Friendship simultaneously.
A Friend node can have friendship with multiple Low Power nodes at the same time,
while a Low Power node can only establish friendship with only one Friend node at
the same time.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FRIEND_LPN_COUNT
children.title: Number of supported LPN nodes

children.help:
Number of incomplete segment lists tracked for each Friends' LPN.
In other words, this determines from how many elements can segmented
messages destined for the Friend queue be received simultaneously.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FRIEND_SEG_RX
children.title: Number of incomplete segment lists per LPN

children.help: Enable this option to be able to act as a Friend Node.
children.name: BLE_MESH_FRIEND
children.title: Support for Friend feature

children.help:
Select this to save the BLE Mesh related rodata code size. Enabling this option
will disable the output of BLE Mesh debug log.
children.name: BLE_MESH_NO_LOG
children.title: Disable BLE Mesh debug logs (minimize bin size)

children.help: Define BLE Mesh trace level for BLE Mesh stack.
children.name: BLE_MESH_STACK_TRACE_LEVEL
children.title: BLE_MESH_STACK
BLE Mesh STACK DEBUG LOG LEVEL

children.help: Define BLE Mesh trace level for BLE Mesh net buffer.
children.name: BLE_MESH_NET_BUF_TRACE_LEVEL
children.title: BLE_MESH_NET_BUF
BLE Mesh NET BUF DEBUG LOG LEVEL

children.help:
Timeout value used by the node to get response of the acknowledged
message which is sent by the client model.
This value indicates the maximum time that a client model waits for
the response of the sent acknowledged messages. If a client model
uses 0 as the timeout value when sending acknowledged messages, then
the default value will be used which is four seconds.
children.name: BLE_MESH_CLIENT_MSG_TIMEOUT
children.title: Timeout(ms) for client message response

children.help: Enable support for Configuration Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_CFG_CLI
children.title: Configuration Client model

children.help: Enable support for Health Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_HEALTH_CLI
children.title: Health Client model

children.help: Enable support for Health Server model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_HEALTH_SRV
children.title: Health Server model
Support for BLE Mesh Foundation models

children.help: Enable support for Generic OnOff Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_ONOFF_CLI
children.title: Generic OnOff Client model

children.help: Enable support for Generic Level Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_LEVEL_CLI
children.title: Generic Level Client model

children.help: Enable support for Generic Default Transition Time Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_DEF_TRANS_TIME_CLI
children.title: Generic Default Transition Time Client model

children.help: Enable support for Generic Power OnOff Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_POWER_ONOFF_CLI
children.title: Generic Power OnOff Client model

children.help: Enable support for Generic Power Level Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_POWER_LEVEL_CLI
children.title: Generic Power Level Client model

children.help: Enable support for Generic Battery Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_BATTERY_CLI
children.title: Generic Battery Client model

children.help: Enable support for Generic Location Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_LOCATION_CLI
children.title: Generic Location Client model

children.help: Enable support for Generic Property Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_PROPERTY_CLI
children.title: Generic Property Client model

children.help: Enable support for Sensor Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SENSOR_CLI
children.title: Sensor Client model

children.help: Enable support for Time Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_TIME_CLI
children.title: Time Client model

children.help: Enable support for Scene Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SCENE_CLI
children.title: Scene Client model

children.help: Enable support for Scheduler Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SCHEDULER_CLI
children.title: Scheduler Client model

children.help: Enable support for Light Lightness Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LIGHT_LIGHTNESS_CLI
children.title: Light Lightness Client model

children.help: Enable support for Light CTL Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LIGHT_CTL_CLI
children.title: Light CTL Client model

children.help: Enable support for Light HSL Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LIGHT_HSL_CLI
children.title: Light HSL Client model

children.help: Enable support for Light XYL Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LIGHT_XYL_CLI
children.title: Light XYL Client model

children.help: Enable support for Light LC Client model.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LIGHT_LC_CLI
children.title: Light LC Client model

children.help: Enable support for Generic server models.
children.name: BLE_MESH_GENERIC_SERVER
children.title: Generic server models

children.help: Enable support for Sensor server models.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SENSOR_SERVER
children.title: Sensor server models

children.help: Enable support for Time and Scenes server models.
children.name: BLE_MESH_TIME_SCENE_SERVER
children.title: Time and Scenes server models

children.help: Enable support for Lighting server models.
children.name: BLE_MESH_LIGHTING_SERVER
children.title: Lighting server models
Support for BLE Mesh Client/Server models

children.help:
This option removes the 96 hour limit of the IV Update Procedure and
lets the state to be changed at any time.
If IV Update test mode is going to be used, this option should be enabled.
children.name: BLE_MESH_IV_UPDATE_TEST
children.title: Test the IV Update Procedure

children.help:
This option is used to decide whether discarding the old SeqAuth when
receiving a segmented message.
children.name: BLE_MESH_DISCARD_OLD_SEQ_AUTH

children.help:
This option adds extra self-tests which are run every time BLE Mesh
networking is initialized.
children.name: BLE_MESH_SELF_TEST
children.title: Perform BLE Mesh self-tests

children.help: This option is used to enable the log of auto-pts test.
children.name: BLE_MESH_BQB_TEST_LOG

children.help: This option is used to enable some internal functions for auto-pts test.
children.name: BLE_MESH_BQB_TEST
children.title: Enable BLE Mesh specific internal test

children.help:
With this option enabled, an unprovisioned device can automatically

children.help:

channel. This is the default value.

For testing, disable this option so that we can measure the output of DAC by internal ADC.
children.name: ADC_DISABLE_DAC
children.title: Disable DAC when ADC2 is used on GPIO 25 and 26

children.help:

If you want to continue using the legacy driver, and don't want to see related deprecation warnings,

children.name: ADC_SUPPRESS_DEPRECATE_WARN

children.help:
Some ESP32s have Two Point calibration values burned into eFuse BLOCK3.
This option will allow the ADC calibration component to characterize the
ADC-Voltage curve using Two Point values if they are available.
children.name: ADC_CAL_EFUSE_TP_ENABLE
children.title: Use Two Point Values

children.help:
Some ESP32s have Vref burned into eFuse BLOCK0. This option will allow
the ADC calibration component to characterize the ADC-Voltage curve using
eFuse Vref if it is available.
children.name: ADC_CAL_EFUSE_VREF_ENABLE
children.title: Use eFuse Vref

children.help:
This option will allow the ADC calibration component to use Lookup Tables
to correct for non-linear behavior in 11db attenuation. Other attenuations
do not exhibit non-linear behavior hence will not be affected by this option.
children.name: ADC_CAL_LUT_ENABLE
children.title: Use Lookup Tables

Wether to suppress the deprecation warnings when using legacy adc calibration

If you want to continue using the legacy driver, and don't want to see related
deprecation warnings, you can enable this option.
children.name: ADC_CALI_SUPPRESS_DEPRECATE_WARN
children.title: Suppress legacy driver deprecated warning

children.help:
Normally only the ISR of SPI master is placed in the IRAM, so that it
can work without the flash when interrupt is triggered.
For other functions, there's some possibility that the flash cache
miss when running inside and out of SPI functions, which may increase
the interval of SPI transactions.
Enable this to put ``queue_trans``, ``get_trans_result`` and
``transmit`` functions into the IRAM to avoid possible cache miss.

This configuration won't be available if `CONFIG_FREERTOS_PLACE_FUNCTIONS_INTO_FLASH` is enabled.

During unit test, this is enabled to measure the ideal case of api.
children.name: SPI_MASTER_IN_IRAM
children.title: Place transmitting functions of SPI master into IRAM

children.help:
Place the SPI master ISR in to IRAM to avoid possible cache miss.

Enabling this configuration is possible only when HEAP_PLACE_FUNCTION_INTO_FLASH
is disabled since the spi master uses can allocate transactions buffers into DMA
memory section using the heap component API that ipso facto has to be placed in IRAM.

Also you can forbid the ISR being disabled during flash writing
access, by add ESP_INTR_FLAG_IRAM when initializing the driver.
children.name: SPI_MASTER_ISR_IN_IRAM
children.title: Place SPI master ISR function into IRAM

children.help:
Normally only the ISR of SPI slave is placed in the IRAM, so that it
can work without the flash when interrupt is triggered.
For other functions, there's some possibility that the flash cache
miss when running inside and out of SPI functions, which may increase
the interval of SPI transactions.
Enable this to put ``queue_trans``, ``get_trans_result`` and
``transmit`` functions into the IRAM to avoid possible cache miss.
children.name: SPI_SLAVE_IN_IRAM
children.title: Place transmitting functions of SPI slave into IRAM

children.help:
Place the SPI slave ISR in to IRAM to avoid possible cache miss.

Also you can forbid the ISR being disabled during flash writing
access, by add ESP_INTR_FLAG_IRAM when initializing the driver.
children.name: SPI_SLAVE_ISR_IN_IRAM
children.title: Place SPI slave ISR function into IRAM

children.help:
Place the TWAI ISR in to IRAM. This will allow the ISR to avoid
cache misses, and also be able to run whilst the cache is disabled
(such as when writing to SPI Flash).
Note that if this option is enabled:
- Users should also set the ESP_INTR_FLAG_IRAM in the driver
configuration structure when installing the driver (see docs for
specifics).
- Alert logging (i.e., setting of the TWAI_ALERT_AND_LOG flag)
will have no effect.
children.name: TWAI_ISR_IN_IRAM
children.title: Place TWAI ISR function into IRAM

children.help:
When the bus-off condition is reached, the REC should be reset to 0 and frozen (via LOM) by the
driver's ISR. However on the ESP32, there is an edge case where the REC will increase before the
driver's ISR can respond in time (e.g., due to the rapid occurrence of bus errors), thus causing the
REC to be non-zero after bus-off. A non-zero REC can prevent bus-off recovery as the bus-off recovery
condition is that both TEC and REC become 0. Enabling this option will add a workaround in the driver
to forcibly reset REC to zero on reaching bus-off.
children.name: TWAI_ERRATA_FIX_BUS_OFF_REC
children.title: Add SW workaround for REC change during bus-off

children.help:
On the ESP32, when a transmit interrupt occurs, and interrupt register is read on the same APB clock
cycle, the transmit interrupt could be lost. Enabling this option will add a workaround that checks the
transmit buffer status bit to recover any lost transmit interrupt.
children.name: TWAI_ERRATA_FIX_TX_INTR_LOST
children.title: Add SW workaround for TX interrupt lost errata

children.help:
On the ESP32, when receiving a data or remote frame, if a bus error occurs in the data or CRC field,
the data of the next received frame could be invalid. Enabling this option will add a workaround that
will reset the peripheral on detection of this errata condition. Note that if a frame is transmitted on
the bus whilst the reset is ongoing, the message will not be receive by the peripheral sent on the bus
during the reset, the message will be lost.
children.name: TWAI_ERRATA_FIX_RX_FRAME_INVALID
children.title: Add SW workaround for invalid RX frame errata

children.help:
On the ESP32, when the RX FIFO overruns and the RX message counter maxes out at 64 messages, the entire
RX FIFO is no longer recoverable. Enabling this option will add a workaround that resets the peripheral
on detection of this errata condition. Note that if a frame is being sent on the bus during the reset
bus during the reset, the message will be lost.
children.name: TWAI_ERRATA_FIX_RX_FIFO_CORRUPT
children.title: Add SW workaround for RX FIFO corruption errata

children.help:
When in the listen only mode, the TWAI controller must not influence the TWAI bus (i.e., must not send
any dominant bits). However, while in listen only mode on the ESP32/ESP32-S2/ESP32-S3/ESP32-C3, the
TWAI controller will still transmit dominant bits when it detects an error (i.e., as part of an active
error frame). Enabling this option will add a workaround that forces the TWAI controller into an error
passive state on initialization, thus preventing any dominant bits from being sent.
children.name: TWAI_ERRATA_FIX_LISTEN_ONLY_DOM
children.title: Add SW workaround for listen only transmits dominant bit errata

children.help:
Wether to suppress the deprecation warnings when using legacy temperature sensor driver
(driver/temp_sensor.h). If you want to continue using the legacy driver,
and don't want to see related deprecation warnings, you can enable this option.

children.help:

If this option is selected, chip will automatically emulate the behaviour of switching,
and about 450B of source codes would be placed into IRAM.

executable when the cache is disabled (e.g. SPI Flash write).

If you want to continue using the legacy driver, and don't want to see related deprecation warnings,

children.help:
Whether to left shift the continuous data to align every bytes to 16 bits in the driver.
On ESP32, although the DAC resolution is only 8 bits,
the hardware requires 16 bits data in continuous mode.
By enabling this option, the driver will left shift 8 bits for the input data automatically.
Only disable this option when you decide to do this step by yourself.
Note that the driver will allocate a new piece of memory to save the converted data.
children.name: DAC_DMA_AUTO_16BIT_ALIGN
children.title: Align the continuous data to 16 bit automatically

children.help:
If enabled, the chip will constantly monitor the connection status of the USB Serial/JTAG port. As long
as the USB Serial/JTAG is connected, a ESP_PM_NO_LIGHT_SLEEP power management lock will be acquired to
prevent the system from entering light sleep.
This option can be useful if serial monitoring is needed via USB Serial/JTAG while power management is
enabled, as the USB Serial/JTAG cannot work under light sleep and after waking up from light sleep.
Note. This option can only control the automatic Light-Sleep behavior. If esp_light_sleep_start() is
called manually from the program, enabling this option will not prevent light sleep entry even if the
USB Serial/JTAG is in use.
children.name: USJ_NO_AUTO_LS_ON_CONNECTION
children.title: Don't enter the automatic light sleep when USB Serial/JTAG port is connected

children.help:
Wether to enable the debug log message for parallel IO driver.
Note that, this option only controls the parallel IO driver log, won't affect other drivers.
children.name: PARLIO_ENABLE_DEBUG_LOG
children.title: Enable debug log

executable when the cache is disabled (e.g. SPI Flash write).
children.name: PARLIO_ISR_IRAM_SAFE
children.title: Parallel IO ISR IRAM-Safe

children.help:
Name of the custom eFuse CSV filename. This path is evaluated
relative to the project root directory.
children.name: EFUSE_CUSTOM_TABLE_FILENAME
children.title: Custom eFuse CSV file

children.help: Allows to generate a structure for eFuse from the CSV file.
children.name: EFUSE_CUSTOM_TABLE
children.title: Use custom eFuse table

children.help:
In addition to the "Simulate eFuse operations in RAM" option, this option just adds
a feature to keep eFuses after reboots in flash memory. To use this mode the partition_table
should have the `efuse` partition. partition.csv: "efuse_em, data, efuse,   ,   0x2000,"

During startup, the eFuses are copied from flash or,
in case if flash is empty, from real eFuse to RAM and then update flash.
This mode is useful when need to keep changes after reboot
(testing secure_boot and flash_encryption).
children.name: EFUSE_VIRTUAL_KEEP_IN_FLASH
children.title: Keep eFuses in flash

children.help: If enabled, log efuse burns. This shows changes that would be made.
children.name: EFUSE_VIRTUAL_LOG_ALL_WRITES
children.title: Log all virtual writes

children.help:
If "n" - No virtual mode. All eFuse operations are real and use eFuse registers.
If "y" - The virtual mode is enabled and all eFuse operations (read and write) are redirected
to RAM instead of eFuse registers, all permanent changes (via eFuse) are disabled.
Log output will state changes that would be applied, but they will not be.

If it is "y", then SECURE_FLASH_ENCRYPTION_MODE_RELEASE cannot be used.
Because the EFUSE VIRT mode is for testing only.

During startup, the eFuses are copied into RAM. This mode is useful for fast tests.
children.name: EFUSE_VIRTUAL
children.title: Simulate eFuse operations in RAM

children.name: EFUSE_CODE_SCHEME_COMPAT_REPEAT
children.title: Repeat, 3/4 and None (common table does not support it)

children.help: Selector eFuse code scheme.
children.name: EFUSE_CODE_SCHEME_SELECTOR
children.title: Coding Scheme Compatibility

children.name: ESP_TLS_USING_WOLFSSL
children.title: wolfSSL (License info in wolfSSL directory README)

children.help:
The ESP-TLS APIs support multiple backend TLS libraries. Currently mbedTLS and WolfSSL are
supported. Different TLS libraries may support different features and have different resource
usage. Consult the ESP-TLS documentation in ESP-IDF Programming guide for more details.
children.name: ESP_TLS_LIBRARY_CHOOSE
children.title: Choose SSL/TLS library for ESP-TLS (See help for more Info)

children.help:
Enable use of Secure Element for ESP-TLS, this enables internal support for
ATECC608A peripheral on ESPWROOM32SE, which can be used for TLS connection.
children.name: ESP_TLS_USE_SECURE_ELEMENT
children.title: Use Secure Element (ATECC608A) with ESP-TLS

children.help:
Enable use of the Digital Signature Peripheral for ESP-TLS.The DS peripheral
can only be used when it is appropriately configured for TLS.
Consult the ESP-TLS documentation in ESP-IDF Programming Guide for more details.
children.name: ESP_TLS_USE_DS_PERIPHERAL
children.title: Use Digital Signature (DS) Peripheral with ESP-TLS

children.help: Enable session ticket support as specified in RFC5077.
children.name: ESP_TLS_CLIENT_SESSION_TICKETS
children.title: Enable client session tickets

children.help: Sets the session ticket timeout used in the tls server.
children.name: ESP_TLS_SERVER_SESSION_TICKET_TIMEOUT
children.title: Server session ticket timeout in seconds

children.help: Enable session ticket support as specified in RFC5077
children.name: ESP_TLS_SERVER_SESSION_TICKETS
children.title: Enable server session tickets

children.help:
Ability to configure and use a certificate selection callback during server handshake,
to select a certificate to present to the client based on the TLS extensions supplied in
the client hello (alpn, sni, etc).
children.name: ESP_TLS_SERVER_CERT_SELECT_HOOK
children.title: Certificate selection hook

children.help:
When this option is enabled, the peer (here, the client) certificate is checked by the server,
however the handshake continues even if verification failed. By default, the
peer certificate is not checked and ignored by the server.

mbedtls_ssl_get_verify_result() can be called after the handshake is complete to
retrieve status of verification.
children.name: ESP_TLS_SERVER_MIN_AUTH_MODE_OPTIONAL
children.title: ESP-TLS Server: Set minimum Certificate Verification mode to Optional

children.help:
Enable support for creating server side SSL/TLS session, available for mbedTLS
as well as wolfSSL TLS library.
children.name: ESP_TLS_SERVER
children.title: Enable ESP-TLS Server

children.help:
Enable support for pre shared key ciphers, supported for both mbedTLS as well as
wolfSSL TLS library.
children.name: ESP_TLS_PSK_VERIFICATION
children.title: Enable PSK verification

children.help:
After enabling this option the esp-tls client will skip the server certificate verification
by default. Note that this option will only modify the default behaviour of esp-tls client
regarding server cert verification. The default behaviour should only be applicable when
no other option regarding the server cert verification is opted in the esp-tls config
(e.g. crt_bundle_attach, use_global_ca_store etc.).
WARNING : Enabling this option comes with a potential risk of establishing a TLS connection
with a server which has a fake identity, provided that the server certificate
is not provided either through API or other mechanism like ca_store etc.
children.name: ESP_TLS_SKIP_SERVER_CERT_VERIFY
children.title: Skip server certificate verification by default (WARNING: ONLY FOR TESTING PURPOSE, READ HELP)

children.help:
You can enable some potentially insecure options. These options should only be used for testing pusposes.
Only enable these options if you are very sure.
children.name: ESP_TLS_INSECURE
children.title: Allow potentially insecure options

children.help:
Enables server verification with Intermediate CA cert, does not authenticate full chain
of trust upto the root CA cert (After Enabling this option client only needs to have Intermediate
CA certificate of the server to authenticate server, root CA cert is not necessary).
children.name: ESP_WOLFSSL_SMALL_CERT_VERIFY
children.title: Enable SMALL_CERT_VERIFY

children.help: Enable detailed debug prints for wolfSSL SSL library.
children.name: ESP_DEBUG_WOLFSSL
children.title: Enable debug logs for wolfSSL

children.help: Place ISR version ADC oneshot mode read function into IRAM.
children.name: ADC_ONESHOT_CTRL_FUNC_IN_IRAM
children.title: Place ISR version ADC oneshot mode read function into IRAM

children.help:
Ensure the ADC continuous mode ISR is IRAM-Safe. When enabled, the ISR handler
will be available when the cache is disabled.
children.name: ADC_CONTINUOUS_ISR_IRAM_SAFE
children.title: ADC continuous mode driver ISR IRAM-Safe

children.help:
Some ESP32s have Two Point calibration values burned into eFuse BLOCK3.
This option will allow the ADC calibration component to characterize the
ADC-Voltage curve using Two Point values if they are available.
children.name: ADC_CALI_EFUSE_TP_ENABLE
children.title: Use Two Point Values

children.help:
Some ESP32s have Vref burned into eFuse BLOCK0. This option will allow
the ADC calibration component to characterize the ADC-Voltage curve using
eFuse Vref if it is available.
children.name: ADC_CALI_EFUSE_VREF_ENABLE
children.title: Use eFuse Vref

children.help:
This option will allow the ADC calibration component to use Lookup Tables
to correct for non-linear behavior in 11db attenuation. Other attenuations
do not exhibit non-linear behavior hence will not be affected by this option.
children.name: ADC_CALI_LUT_ENABLE
children.title: Use Lookup Tables

children.help:
By default, this is set. The ADC oneshot driver will disable the output of the
corresponding DAC channels:
ESP32:   IO25 and IO26
ESP32S2: IO17 and IO18

Disable this option so as to measure the output of DAC by internal ADC, for test usage.
children.name: ADC_DISABLE_DAC_OUTPUT
children.title: Disable DAC when ADC2 is in use

children.help:
On ESP32C3 and ESP32S3, ADC2 Digital Controller is not stable. Therefore,
ADC2 continuous mode is not suggested on ESP32S3 and ESP32C3

If you stick to this, you can enable this option to force use ADC2 under above conditions.
For more details, you can search for errata on espressif website.
children.name: ADC_CONTINUOUS_FORCE_USE_ADC2_ON_C3_S3
children.title: Force use ADC2 continumous mode on ESP32S3 or ESP32C3

children.help:
On ESP32C3, ADC2 Digital Controller is not stable. Therefore,
ADC2 oneshot mode is not suggested on ESP32C3

If you stick to this, you can enable this option to force use ADC2 under above conditions.
For more details, you can search for errata on espressif website.
children.name: ADC_ONESHOT_FORCE_USE_ADC2_ON_C3
children.title: Force use ADC2 oneshot mode on ESP32C3

children.help:
If enabled, WiFi & Bluetooth coexistence is controlled by software rather than hardware.
Recommended for heavy traffic scenarios. Both coexistence configuration options are
automatically managed, no user intervention is required.
If only Bluetooth is used, it is recommended to disable this option to reduce binary file
size.
children.name: ESP_COEX_SW_COEXIST_ENABLE
children.title: Software controls WiFi/Bluetooth coexistence

children.help:
If enabled, HW External coexistence arbitration is managed by GPIO pins.
It can support three types of wired combinations so far which are 1-wired/2-wired/3-wired.
User can select GPIO pins in application code with configure interfaces.

This function depends on BT-off
because currently we do not support external coex and internal coex simultaneously.
children.name: ESP_COEX_EXTERNAL_COEXIST_ENABLE
children.title: External Coexistence

children.help:
Functions esp_err_to_name() and esp_err_to_name_r() return string representations of error codes from a
pre-generated lookup table. This option can be used to turn off the use of the look-up table in order to
save memory but this comes at the price of sacrificing distinguishable (meaningful) output string
representations.
children.name: ESP_ERR_TO_NAME_LOOKUP
children.title: Enable lookup of error code strings

children.help: Select the communication interface between MAC and PHY chip.
children.name: ETH_PHY_INTERFACE
children.title: PHY interface

children.help:
MAC will get RMII clock from outside.
Note that ESP32 only supports GPIO0 to input the RMII clock.
children.name: ETH_RMII_CLK_INPUT
children.title: Input RMII clock from external

children.help:
ESP32 can generate RMII clock by internal APLL.
This clock can be routed to the external PHY device.
ESP32 supports to route the RMII clock to GPIO0/16/17.
children.name: ETH_RMII_CLK_OUTPUT
children.title: Output RMII clock from internal

children.help: Select external or internal RMII clock.
children.name: ETH_RMII_CLK_MODE
children.title: RMII clock mode

children.help: ESP32 only supports GPIO0 to input the RMII clock.
children.name: ETH_RMII_CLK_IN_GPIO

children.help:
GPIO0 can be set to output a pre-divided PLL clock (test only!).
Enabling this option will configure GPIO0 to output a 50MHz clock.
In fact this clock doesn't have directly relationship with EMAC peripheral.
Sometimes this clock won't work well with your PHY chip. You might need to
add some extra devices after GPIO0 (e.g. inverter).
Note that outputting RMII clock on GPIO0 is an experimental practice.
If you want the Ethernet to work with WiFi, don't select GPIO0 output mode for stability.
children.name: ETH_RMII_CLK_OUTPUT_GPIO0
children.title: Output RMII clock from GPIO0 (Experimental!)

children.help: Set the GPIO number to output RMII Clock.
children.name: ETH_RMII_CLK_OUT_GPIO
children.title: RMII clock GPIO number

children.help: Set the size of each buffer used by Ethernet MAC DMA.
children.name: ETH_DMA_BUFFER_SIZE
children.title: Ethernet DMA buffer size (Byte)

children.help:
Number of DMA receive buffers. Each buffer's size is ETH_DMA_BUFFER_SIZE.
Larger number of buffers could increase throughput somehow.
children.name: ETH_DMA_RX_BUFFER_NUM
children.title: Amount of Ethernet DMA Rx buffers

children.help:
Number of DMA transmit buffers. Each buffer's size is ETH_DMA_BUFFER_SIZE.
Larger number of buffers could increase throughput somehow.
children.name: ETH_DMA_TX_BUFFER_NUM
children.title: Amount of Ethernet DMA Tx buffers

children.help:
Ethernet MAC engine on ESP32 doesn't feature a flow control logic.
The MAC driver can perform a software flow control if you enable this option.
Note that, if the RX buffer number is small, enabling software flow control will
cause obvious performance loss.
children.name: ETH_SOFT_FLOW_CONTROL
children.title: Enable software flow control
